Award.AwardTitle: Compressive Sensing Based Inference in Distributed Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective

The objective of this program is to develop efficient algorithms and obtain performance bounds
for decentralized inference in the reduced dimensional subspace obtained via Compressive Sens-
ing based measurement schemes in resource-constrained distributed networks.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the proposed program is that it will advance the theory of Compressive
Sensing to resource-constrained distributed systems with multiple measurement vectors. While
there is a considerable amount of work in the literature for Compressive Sensing based signal
processing with a single measurement vector, its extension to multiple measurement vectors in
resource-constrained distributed systems is still at its infancy. The transformative nature of the
proposed research lies in its potential to identify and solve decentralized inference problems based
on low dimensional sampling schemes exploiting structured models of the multiple measurement
vectors collected at distributed nodes.

Broader Impacts

The proposed research will have direct impact on advancing the theory and practice, as well as
on education and training. The broader impacts are: 1) Development of efficient low dimensional signal processing techniques for decentralized inference in resource-constrained distributed networks exploiting structured properties (sparsity as well as models that go beyond the simple sparsity model) of large data sets. 2) Efficient design approaches for distributed inference networks with a wide variety of applications including environmental monitoring, remote sensing, radar networks, cognitive
radio networks and bio-medical applications with high dimensional data. 3) Development of graduate level courses on signal processing and inference for large data sets. Mentoring of graduate student in research methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Intelligent processing of large and heterogeneous data generated in many distributed networks will lead to new design approaches for solving fundamental inference problems efficiently. The goal of the project was to investigate different low dimensional representation models (e.g., sparsity, union of subspaces, etc...) for such large data sets, and exploit efficient compression techniques while performing the specific tasks. Our research contributions spanned two main directions; (i) exploitation of the theories and concepts developed in compressive sensing (CS) for solving inference problems and (ii) development of sparsity aware algorithms in a distributed/decentralized  manner utilizing scarce network resources. A simple but universal and agnostic mechanism suggested by the theory of CS is to compress data via low dimensional random projections. Most existing work related to CS focuses on signal reconstruction. In this report, using the compressed data acquired at distributed nodes via the CS measurement scheme, efficient algorithms for detection, estimation and tracking were developed in distributed as well as decentralized manners utilizing scarce network resources. The outcome of the project provides new insights on processing sparse or compressible signals for different inference tasks saving computational power and time. The outcome of the project has a significant impact on the design and implementation of efficient and flexible hardware and software to perform fundamental inference tasks in distributed networks which are designed for a wide variety of applications including environmental monitoring, remote sensing,  civilian, commercial, bio-medical and security applications.

We have disseminated the research results via publications in archival journals including IEEE Transaction on Signal Processing, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing Over Networks, and IEEE Wireless Communication Letters, presentations at top tier technical conferences including ICASSP, Asilomar, and GlobalSIP. Unpublished work including papers under review is made available online at https://arxiv.org. We also pursued technology transfer opportunities by leveraging our collaborations with industry and, in particular, the current role of PI Varshney as the director of CASE was full utilized. CASE is a New York Center of Advanced Technology with technology transfer and economic development as its main missions. A STTR project on 'High Quality/Low Dimension Data for Sensor Integration' (Phase I and Phase II) awarded by AFRL leveraged outcomes of this project.

The education plan focused on the integration of the research results into classroom teaching. Material from this project output was taught as a part of an existing course on Detection and Estimation (ELE 851) as well as in a special topics course where about half the course covered compressive sensing topics and research results from this project. Graduate students (including two female students) involved in this research played an active role in carrying out the research activities. Part of research output appears in three completed theses. We also gave opportunity for undergraduate students  to take part in active scientific research via the summer intern program at Syracuse University.
